summary: This document is a series of email exchanges on August 10, 2019, between U.S. Attorney's Office personnel and others regarding the death of Jeffrey Epstein. It reveals frantic communications, concerns about hoax calls, lack of official information, and frustration over the Bureau of Prisons (BOP) releasing information to the press before informing prosecutors and defense counsel.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The subject of the emails; reported to have passed away in custody at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) after an apparent suicide attempt.

events.title: Epstein's Death and Aftermath
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein is reported to have passed away in custody at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) after an apparent suicide attempt. There is confusion and concern over the release of information, potential hoax calls about body retrieval, and the adequacy of the autopsy/investigation.

events.title: Hoax Call Regarding Epstein's Body
events.description: Defense counsel reports a phone call from an individual claiming to be an MCC investigator, stating Epstein's body was ready for pickup and providing a phone number. This raises concerns about hoaxes targeting Epstein's associates.

events.title: BOP Press Release on Epstein's Death
events.description: The Bureau of Prisons issues a public press release about Epstein's death before providing basic information (time, cause of death) to the U.S. Attorney's Office or defense counsel, causing significant frustration.

locations: Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC), New York, New York 10007
keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein died in federal custody on August 10, 2019, at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York after an apparent suicide attempt.
Epstein's defense counsel received a suspicious phone call from someone claiming to be an MCC investigator about retrieving Epstein's body, raising concerns about hoaxes targeting his associates.

The Bureau of Prisons (BOP) issued a public press release about Epstein's death before providing basic facts to the U.S. Attorney's Office, causing extreme frustration among prosecutors and defense attorneys.
The U.S. Attorney's Office and defense counsel were desperate for basic information (time and cause of death) hours after the incident, highlighting a breakdown in official communication.
There were immediate concerns from defense counsel about whether there had been enough time for a full autopsy and investigation before the body was potentially released.
